content:
Hi @T-compiler/meeting; the triage meeting will take place in about 2h
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

Scheduled checkins from:

  • @wg-incr-comp by @pnkfelix @Wesley Wiser : anything to share?
  • @WG-llvm by @nagisa (past summary)
LLVM 13 has been branched on Tuesday, upgrade in progress at https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/87570.
Hi @T-compiler/meeting ! triage meeting starting now; leave a :wave: to show you’re here.

We’ll start off with ~8 minutes for

Announcements
• Tomorrow 2021-07-30T10:00:00-04:00: We have our planning meeting for the August steering meeting cycle. There is currently one proposal, perhaps more ideas.
• :confetti: Today July, 29th release Rust stable 1.54 :confetti:
MCPs/FCPs

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • "Make resolve_instance fallible" compiler-team#449
    • "Reproducible command line + determinism" compiler-team#450

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "Add different entry points for x.py" compiler-team#396 (last comment: 6 months ago)
    • "rustdoc is using rustc_ast_pretty, would it be possible to make it somewhat "stable"?" compiler-team#403 (last comment: 5 months ago)
    • "Don't steal the resolver when lowering HIR; instead store an immutable resolver in TyCtxt" compiler-team#437 (last comment: about 48 days ago)
    • "CI should exercise (subset of) tests under --stage 1" compiler-team#439 (last comment: about 27 days ago)
    • "Accept pc in place of unknown and unknown in place of pc for x86_64 and i?86 targets" compiler-team#441 (last comment: about 27 days ago)
    • "Non exhaustive reachable patterns lint" compiler-team#445 (last comment: about 12 days ago)
Oh, that reminds me: I started an Action Item page: https://hackmd.io/5BtjuenFTn6M74IDwLOjgw
(the reason I mention it is that I want to add an action item to revise the MCP templating to include info about last zulip activity in addition to last github activity. Adding now.)
oh we discussed that last week. Can I put myself in that .md?
@apiraino yes, I want people to feel free to update it. If you need permissions, let me know.

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • "Write text output files to stdout if options like -o - or --emit asm=- are provided" compiler-team#431
    • "Preserve, clarify, and extend debug information" rust#83947

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "Encode spans relative to the enclosing item" compiler-team#443
    • "Don't abort compilation after giving a lint error" compiler-team#447
    • "Rename various internal things" compiler-team#451

• Accepted MCPs
    • No new accepted proposals this time.

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • "Stabilize const_fn_transmute, const_fn_union" rust#85769
    • "Stabilize arbitrary_enum_discriminant" rust#86860
WG checkins

• @wg-incr-comp by @pnkfelix @Wesley Wiser

    The working group has been largely dormant. pnkfelix is hoping to fire things up again, and is seeking input about when/how to drive activity.
@nagisa if you have anything to report for WG-llvm, feel free to post it (either in channel, or in agenda doc itself).

pnkfelix said:

  • :confetti: Today July, 29th release Rust stable 1.54 :confetti:

I noticed there’s no blog post up yet. remind me: is there a specific time that we try to get it out by?
From skimming #t-release > 1.54 release , it seems like things are moving forward; there just might be a slight delay due to some last minute revisions to the post?
okay then
Backport nominations
T-compiler stable / T-compiler beta

• "Always preserve sub-obligations in the projection cache" rust#85868
    • discussed last week
    • Discussion seems was oriented to not backport this to 1.54, to re-enable incr-comp (at least we now have more useful error messages) and attempt to merge it into next beta 1.55
    • makes sense to remove beta-backport nomination?
if this hasn’t landed in nightly yet, then it probably won’t be part of the 1.55-beta cut
I think we need to get this reviewed & merged on nightly before we talk about beta backports.
but it also seems premature to discuss beta backporting
right
but at the same time
I don’t want to remove the nomination
I would like to leave it nominated though so we remember to revisit in the future.
because I don’t want to forget
yes exactly
glad to see the co-leads are aligned. :)
so lets just move along then. If we have to skip each week, so be it
(but ideally we’d get this landed on nightly soonish
I have a last minute beta nomination (+ self accepted), so FYI: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/87483 (an ICE with a one-line fix)
maybe we should reassign review of PR #85868 ? @Matthew Jasper are you around?
@Matthew Jasper hasn’t had much activity lately
I’m thinking we should reassign review
I’ll take action item to find new reviewer, and assign to myself to also reflect that fact.
• No stable nominations for T-compiler this time.

T-rustdoc stable / T-rustdoc beta

  • No beta nominations for T-rustdoc this time.
  • No stable nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

• "Encode spans relative to the enclosing item" rust#84373
    • opened by @cjgillot
    • assigned to @Aaron Hill @mw @Vadim Petrochenkov
    • @cjgillot opended MCP #443 (currently in closing FCP phase)
    • discussed last week, @wg-incr-comp could have a discussion about this after the 1.54 release and the next beta cut
I think that still summarizes things well. I did mention above that @wg-incr-comp has been dormant; things like this would be good activity drivers
but I don’t think it needs further discussion in this meeting

• "Wrap libraries in linker groups, allowing backwards/circular references" rust#85805
    • discussed last week
    • @nagisa commented it could be potentially troublesome
    • @Vadim Petrochenkov mentioned to postpone for a few months
    • @pnkfelix suggested to draft a MCP to boost signal for this PR

yeah, I still think this needs an MCP. I was going to try to dig in more in order to write a coherent comment saying so, but I now think a better path would be for me to reach out to joshtriplett (the PR author) about it directly
(“better path” ==> less effort for pnkfelix path)
The link to the comment is broken
let me fix
fixed

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 1 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 0 of those are unassigned
  • 79 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 53 of those are unassigned
  • 1 P-critical, 0 P-high, 1 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 0 P-critical, 2 P-high, 0 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 1 P-critical, 44 P-high, 80 P-medium, 9 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable
P-critical

T-compiler

  • "Unstable fingerprints - what to do on beta (and stable)" rust#84970
So: Today is D-day re rust#84970
(i.e. the first stable release with incr-comp re-enabled since 1.52.0)
I suggest that we keep rust#84970 open
and we keep it at P-critical for another week
if we don’t see a flood of bug reports, then we can talk about downgrading priority next week.
As for outright closing of the issue… @Aaron Hill , what do you think? I suspect it still serves a good purpose as a meta-bug tracking the various specific issues that have been uncovered?
I think we should leave it open as long as there are unresolved issues (especially since the bug is linked from the ICE message).
I think we can close it once we merge https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/85868
the fact that its linked from the ICE message is indeed important
The 'recursion_limit' evaluate_obligation ICE really isn't in the same category as the others
that's true
we don’t need to keep it open forever
but once https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/85868 is meregd, I think we can consider any new issues as one-off problems
Agreed but I think we should also be willing to reopen if new issues are discovered.
I think I agree with that
any new issues?
as in, if end users hit it
because we want their experience when they visit the issue to reflect their reality
My thinking is that at some point, we should start considering this as 'just' another ICE
e.g. we don't have a dedicated tracking issue for all ICEs resulting from parser recovery
if we get to that point, then we should consider removing the specialized diagnostic

Aaron Hill said:

e.g. we don't have a dedicated tracking issue for all ICEs resulting from parser recovery

(maybe we should, though.)
I think the tracking issue makes sense when it's a common issue that lots of users are having
if it's a bunch of unrelated issues that are uncommon, and just happen to be related in terms of the root cause
then I don't think a tracking issue is particularly useful

basically, I don’t want to give our users the a bad impression. If they hit an ICE that tells them “visit this specific bug”, and that bug is closed saying “its all fixed!”, then that user is going to either say “you shuld reopen this”, or they won’t report their bug, etc
I think keeping the issue open as long as we have the diagnostic is a good idea
Okay great
but at some point, I think we should unify the handling with other ICES in the compiler
the haming?
typo, sorry
okay, well, I think that covers everything here
Until we start seeing user responses to incr-comp for 1.54.0
(good or bad!)

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

• "match an std::cmp::Ordering generates less optimized code in nightly" rust#86511
    • issue was commented and a bit discussed but probably needs an owner
    • WG-prioritization tentatively assigned a P-high to make it float and perhaps not miss the next stable
okay this definitely hit 1.54.0
I don’t think its likely to be a true P-high
I think, since last time we discussed, it may have been bisected more precisely...
or maybe that bisection had been done even before most recent discussion… in any case, bisection blames PR #84993
the perf results for PR #84993 were largely improvements: “significant” green, while the reds seem insignificant in degree
there’s a linked zulip thread to the prioritization discussion, but maybe there should be a zulip thread in either #t-compiler/performance or #t-compiler itself?
I guess @eddyb had a recent idea for recreating the old behavior
so, if anything, I guess someone could look into that
Personally, I think the way to go is to offer to mentor @Simon Chan drive that investigation
using the code that @eddyb provided. Anyone interested in doing that?
I’ll see about writing up a comment suggesting that to @Simon Chan

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • No unassigned P-high nightly regressions this time.

Performance logs

triage logs 2021-07-27

A very quiet week with only improvements. There was one possible regression, but it was removed from consideration due to only barely impacting a somewhat noisy stress-test benchmark. Untriaged pull requests continue to pile up, but there is still not a good process for dealing with them.

Triage done by @rylev.

0 Regressions, 3 Improvements, 0 Mixed; 0 of them in rollups

Regressions

Support HIR wf checking for function signatures #87265

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 1.1% on full builds of externs-opt)
  • Given that this only impacts the somewhat noisy externs stress-test benchmark, it's not clear that we should treat this as an actual regression.

Improvements

  • Improve caching during trait evaluation #86946
  • Make mir borrowck's use of opaque types independent of the typeck query's result #87287
  • Store all HIR owners in the same container #83723

Mixed

None

Untriaged Pull Requests

  • #87244 Better diagnostics with mismatched types due to implicit static lifetime
  • #86777 Include terminators in instance size estimate
  • #86698 Move OnDiskCache to rustc_query_impl.
  • #86588 Rollup of 8 pull requests
  • #86034 Change entry point to 🛡️ against 💥 💥-payloads
  • #84560 Inline Iterator as IntoIterator.
(i’m going to add an unassigned action item to drive down the length of that Untriaged Pull Requests list)

Nags requiring follow up

None
holy cow we’ve gotten to the nominations and its only 43 minutes into the meeting. Ah I love release day!

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

• "Binary size is significant increased from 1.46.0 to 1.51.0" rust#86610
    • briefly mentioned last week, discussion postponed to this week
    • issue nominated as FIY for T-compiler
    • perhaps related to one or more issues about the same theme (see mentioned issues, ex. rust#86431 was mentioned)
    • Actionable for this issue? Can this be tracked in perf? Worth a P-high to keep it visible on the radar?

to be clear: this is talking about the size of binaries generated for end-user’s compiled object code. (It is not addressing, for example, the size of our distribution; I suspect that’s grown as well, but that’s a different class of problem.)
I think all we can hope to do in short term is add a metric to perf.rlo
I added an unowned action item for that

Quick thought on this action items list: I chose a hackmd doc because its a minimal overhead and flexible system. But @mw pointed out that a tabular format, maybe a full-fledged spreadsheet might be better. Other options include Project Tracking (GitHub has one already), Kanban… or even just using the rust-lang/rust issues tracker (e.g. we could have an “action item” label on issues, and then the issue title serves as the item’s description).
Feedback welcome on other options here. The main thing is that I want it to be really easy to add and remove action items. I’ve been thinking that maybe a zulip bot is the best thing for that.
anyway I think after we get binary size tracking into perf.rlo, we can unnominate #86610. Unless we want to take more targetted action on addressing this size increase.

RFC

  • No nominated RFCs for T-compiler this time.
I think ease of use is the main thing. I'd also try avoid requiring us to manage user accounts in yet another system. We're already using hackmd so that has some advantages.

imo the hackmd is fine as those tasks perhaps tend to not have a long lifespan (or "lifetime" ah-ah). Also difficult to bind that list to a single repo (ex. I'd like to fix the agenda and that's more a rust-lang/triagebot thing)
One nice thing about hackmd, that I only learned about recently, is that you can trivially embed one document in another, e.g. via {%hackmd 5BtjuenFTn6M74IDwLOjgw %}
that's really cool !
So that opens up other avenues for how to structure things
(e.g. I have made my own personal todo list that, in addition to my private todos, also embeds the action item lists for T-compiler and T-lang)
I am only concerned about noisiness as the backlog grows. If we are good about pruning it as things are addressed, potentially moving lines to a new linked document, it should be fine.
yes, we definitely need to garbage collect
since we are sitting here with five minutes left
I wanted to draw attention to this “old” bug: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/82151
I haven’t had time to investigate carefully how much of this is a cargo issue vs a rustc issue
but it definitely has impacted some users
ah, fun: The 1.54 release blog post is up
Special thanks to @Wesley Wiser and @Esteban Küber for your last minute help with the blog post text there about incr-comp
And as a last minute reminder again: Tomorrow at 2021-07-30T10:00:00-04:00 we have our planning meeting for the august steering meeting cycle!
Great meeting y’all! Thanks to all of you in @T-compiler/meeting for attending! :wave:

Draft for this week's agenda is available at:
https://hackmd.io/1UfGXIz4Sdy0EwNjcxarnw?view

Scheduled checkins from:

  • @WG-mir-opt by @oli
  • @WG-polymorphization by @davidtwco
